Erlinda  has been in this business for 18 years. In the future, Erlinda would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy materials for the repair of her fishing boat.

loans.name: Ummy

texts.en: Ummy, 39, is a hard-working business woman. She is married and blessed with three children. For the past 10 years, she has managed a salon business to make a living. She has employed four people to help her in her business. In the next five years, she wants to open a new salon. She is requesting for a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy a hair drier. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, she has been able to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy a hair drier for her salon.

loans.name: Neneth

texts.en:
Neneth is 40 years old and married with two children.

Neneth works hard to provide for her family. She runs a business fattening pigs in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional piglets, feed and vitamins.

Neneth has borrowed and paid 18 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the pig fattening business for 10 years and earns additional income from her sari-sari store.

Neneth aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets, feed and vitamins.

loans.name: Pedro Pablo

texts.es: Pablo Emilio tiene 43 años, su actividad es una pulpería y venta de ropa. Hace más de 5 años que tiene este negocio. Inicio porque él siempre le ha gustado tener un medio de vida con el cual pueda mejorar los ingresos de su hogar. Pedro realizara este crédito para la compra de granos básicos, golosinas, refrescos, entre otros.
texts.en: Pablo Emilio is 43 years old. His business is a general store and the sale of clothing.  He has had this business for 5 years.  He started it because he always liked having a means of being able to improve the income of his home.  Pedro will invest this loan in the purchase of basic grains, candies, refreshments and other products.

loans.use: to purchase basic grains, candies, refreshments and other products.

loans.name: Kim Eng

texts.en: Kim Eng is a farmer who earns $1 per day. Her husband is a farmer and sells palm products earning $3 per day. They have four children; all are working and each earns $3 per day. Every month, Kim Eng has to spend $40 on food, $10 on transportation, and $10 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $500 to buy brick and cement for repairing her house. This loan will help her family to have a better house to live in.

loans.use: To buy brick and cement for repairing her house.

loans.name: Romulo

texts.en:
Romulo is 62 years old, married, and has three adult children.  He farms three hectares of rice fields. His 40 years in farming and his experience leads him to develop his expertise in farming. His dream is to maintain his business and leave it to his three children because he knows that he is getting old.

Romulo is proud that despite the challenges he encountered the love remains in his family. He is also proud that being a farmer, he successfully sent his children to school where they finished their education. 

Romulo’s capital for the sustenance of his farm is from the lenders. Romulo can now save some of his earnings but still not enough to provide for his needs in farming. Therefore, Romulo is requesting for a loan for 50,000 PHP, which he will use to buy fertilizers, seeds, herbicides, and insecticides and to pay his laborers.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds, herbicides, and insecticides and to pay his laborers.

loans.name: Dania Margarita

texts.es:
La Sra.  Dania tiene treinta y ocho años de edad es madre de soltera de tres hijos los cuales se encuentran en edad escolar y todavía dependen de ella. 
Ella acude nuevamente a las oficinas de ceprodel para solicitar un nuevo préstamo para la compra de medicamentos para su mama y para pagos de pre matriculas de colegiatura de sus tres hijos.
texts.en: Dania is 38 years old and the single mother of three children who are school aged and still dependent on her.  She calls on Ceprodel once more to request a new loan to buy medicine for her mother and to pay for her three children’s school tuition.

loans.use: to buy medicine for her mother.

loans.name: Silas

texts.en:
Silas is age 50 and married. He has six children, four adults and two minors, with the latter still schooling. 

He has been in active farming for 24 years. His farm currently produces milk, bananas and mangoes for the local market. He also runs a retail shop dealing in cereals.

Silas made a loan request with Juhudi Kilimo amounting to 25,000 KES to purchase poultry birds and spread his risk from dairy farming, which has been his main source of income. He hopes to earn more income and open up his banana farming for heavy commercial purposes. He says the income will also help him educate his last two children.

Silas says he is challenged by poor rainfalls and markets that offer poor prices for farming outputs. He mentions, however, that Juhudi Kilimo is helping farmers with loans that are processed quickly.

loans.use: To buy poultry birds.

loans.name: Lidia Gloria

texts.es:
Lidia de 48 años, Con la ayuda de Dios pudo salir adelante vendiendo cosméticos de belleza ya que su esposo la abandono; y se dedico a esta actividad.

Realiza su trabajo sola todos los días sin horarios fijos y sus dificultades son la delincuencia del sector y la gran competitividad. Quiere es prestamo para comprar cosmeticos, perfumes etc. 

No esta casada pero tiene hijos y todos son mayores de edad. Su meta a alcanzar es poder terminar de construir su casa.
texts.en:
Lidia, 48, with God’s help was able to get ahead selling beauty cosmetics since her husband abandoned her and went into this business.

She works every day with no fixed work schedule.  Her difficulties are crime in the sector and the high level of competition.  She wants the loan to buy cosmetics, perfumes, etc.

She’s not married but has children who are adults.  Her goal is to be able to finish building her house.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics.

loans.name: Dolgorkhand

texts.en:
Dolgorkhand, 38, runs a tailoring business.  She has been doing her business for 18 years non-stop. She lives with her husband and her 3 children in Kherlen, a western boundary town in Mongolia.  In addition to her tailoring shop, she sells natural salt with her friend Enkhtuya in the market. They have started their business together 2 years ago and now they already have their own permanent customers. 

Dolgorkhand and her friend bring the raw salt from other regions which are located far away, then process it.  This requires a truck for transportation and other expenses.   This month they plan to increase their working capital to extend sales volume. The loan she is taking will be used to buy salt in large amount to increase their sales volume.

loans.use: buy grocery salt

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice is a 23-year-old married woman with two children who are not in school. She has had a business of selling food at a food stall in Yambio, South Sudan for two years.
Joice is requesting this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase sugar and oil. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase sugar and oil for sale.

loans.name: Kuña Guapa Group

texts.es:
Kuña Guapa es el grupo formado en la ciudad de Luque, se unieron con la esperanza de un futuro mejor para sus familias. Ellas son personas muy trabajadoras que día a día se esfuerzan por seguir creciendo no solo en lo económico sino también en lo personal.
Florinda es una de estas mujeres, ella se dedica a la venta de lencerías de todo tipo, tanto de hombres como para mujeres.Comenta que gracias a la buena calidad de los productos, y sumado a los buenos precios que tiene, ha podido formarse ya una buena clientela. Este trabajo la ha ayudado a salir adelante y a mantener el día a día de su hogar.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de lencerías, con lo cual podrá surtirse para tener una mayor cantidad de prendas que poder ofrecer a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Kuña Guapa is the name of the group formed in the city of Luque. They got together in the hope of a better future for their families. They are very hardworking people who work day to day to keep growing, not only financially but personally.   

Florinda is one of these women. She sells underwear of all types, for women and for men. She remarks that thanks to the good quality of the products, together with the prices she has, she has been able to form a good clientele. This job has helped her get ahead and support her home day to day.
  
She is asking for the loan to buy underwear to be able to stock up and have a larger quantity of items to offer her customers.

loans.use: to buy underwear to later sell

loans.name: Gaddy

texts.fr:
NAHIMANA a 45 ans, il est marrie, il a 8 enfants dont le plus grand a 21 ans et le plus petit a 2 ans. 7 enfants vont à l`école.NAHIMANA a étudie 3 école sécondaire.

Il sillicite ce crédit pour acheter la parcel .il n`attend aucune difficultes pour le remboursement.

Ses ambitions est d`avoir sa propre maison et éduquer ses enfants.
texts.en:
GASANA is 45 years old and married. He has eight children. The eldest is 21, the youngest is 2. Seven of them attend school. GASANA has three years of secondary education.

He's seeking this loan to buy a land lot. He does not foresee any difficulty in repaying the loan. He ambitions to have his own house and educate his children.

loans.use: to buy a land lot

loans.name: Hamit

texts.en:
Hamit a vulnerable ethnic Egyptian Albanian who is a very long time client of VFA and in excellent standards, wants to buy food for the pigs and piglets.Currently he's got 4 saws and a pig including piglets. He receives a monthly retirement pension of $54 whereas his wife about $59. However, they work hard and from the pigs they earn an annual gross income of about $7000 with the expenses (food for the animals) of this activity being $1100 without including here the labour work and other veterinary expenses if needed.
Kindly note that Hamit's family fall below the national poverty level.

loans.use: to buy food for the piglets

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en: I have had my business for 10 years and I am dedicated to repairing electronics Duch as TVs, stoves, DVD players, toasters, and others. I have good clients that provide me with work. Currently I have 2 helpers in my shop. The gains are considerable as they help me to have my business and maintain my home.

loans.use: To buy tools and materials.

loans.name: Thérèse

texts.en:
Divorced from her husband two years ago, Mrs Thérèse M. is a dedicated and courageous woman. Her four (4) children are her responsibility. Each day, she fights to be able to provide for them. Her business is the preparation and sale of local meals. Having a sense for good work, she keeps her restaurant clean. That has made her worthy of a large and very faithful clientele. Because of this, the demand is very high and Mrs M. wants to use some financial aid to satisfy her clients more efficiently. The loan of $750 will allow her to stock supplies such as corn, oil and fish etc. These ingredients are indispensable in the preparation of her meals. The earnings from this activity will allow her to better care for her children.

Translated from French by Susan Bell, Kiva Volunteer.

Divorcée avec son mari il y a 2 ans, Madame M. Thérèse est une femme dévouée et courageuse. Ses quatre (4) enfants sont restés à sa charge. Chaque jour, elle ne cesse de se battre pour pouvoir subvenir à leurs besoins. Son activité est la préparation et la vente des repas locaux. Ayant le sens du travail bien fait, elle tient son restaurant toujours très propre. Ce qui lui vaut une clientèle importante et très fidèle. De ce fait, la demande est très élevée et Madame M. veut bénéficier d’un appui financier pouvant lui permettre de satisfaire efficacement ses clients. Le crédit de $750 qu’elle sollicite va lui permettre de stocker les denrées (maïs, huile, poissons etc.) indispensable à la préparation de ses mets. Les bénéfices de cette activité l’aideront à mieux prendre en charge ses enfants.

loans.use: to stock the supplies needed for the preparation of local meals

loans.name: Omohimoria

texts.en: Mr. Omohimoria G. hails from Benin City in the Edo State of Nigeria. He is married with five children. He deals with the sales & repair of refrigerators for the community and promises to expand his business with the loan.

loans.use: To improve on the business

loans.name: Maria De La Cruz

texts.en:
Maria is a young mother of 5 children. For the past few years she had been able to sustain the family employing her husband to attend to the clients who frequent their cafeteria/night club. The husband does the hard labor, while Maria is the administrator.

Their business is located in a community that was built by a foreign government grant wherein their homes are built of thin sheets of cement, sprayed on metallic sightings, with wooden structure roofs topped by asphalt shingles. The community consists of about 500 living units where approximately 3000 people live. Thus, Maria’s business together with a few other similar micro-businesses serve the night time recreational needs of the community. As you might expect, the cafeteria has very old and decrepit boom box for sound equipment. They can only function when there is electricity, which is approximately half of the time. As evident in the picture, they have a refreshment chilling unit. But, Maria and her husband suffered perhaps not so coincidentally the loss of all their goods as a result of robbery. (Najayo correctional facility, the most modern correctional facility of the Dominican Republic, happens to be about a kilometer away from this community).

Maria hopes to get back on track with her business with this loan; however, she does hint that she wants to repay as soon as possible so that she can take a larger loan. Her husband is already working on reinforcing the windows and the doors to their 200sq. ft. business space.

loans.use: Inventory for Cafeteria

loans.name: Alusine

texts.en: Alusine K. is a petty trader, who owns a small grocery store in Kabala town of Sierra Leone.  He is married with five children and works side by side with his wife who is also selling second hand clothes. Alusine also assists other traders by providing storage service.  He would like to increase the service by renting more stores and increasing his grocery stock.  He is therefore requesting a loan of  $200.

loans.use: Purchase more stores to rent as storage and increase grocery stock.

loans.name: Adja

texts.en: Adja is married and has six children. She sells  mangos, oranges, and pineapples. She has been in that  business for years. Adja took a loan from HELP Africa in the past and  was able to repay it on time. Now, she wants a loan to  build a stand and buy more  fruits. By doing so, Adja will expand her business  and make her  place more attractive and cleaner  for  her customers. Then, she will be able to sell her fruits more quickly  and not let them spoil. Adja will also be able to make more profit and repay her loan on time  and with part of  her profit, she will take care of her six children.

loans.use: Buy  fruit for re-sale

loans.name: Aiofaiva

texts.en: Aiofaiva is a 33-year-old lady who is married with two children. She has applied for this loan in order to buy materials and supplies such as sugar, cordials and plastic cups for her business. Aiofaiva sells the ice cakes (popsicles in bags) at the local school five days per week and in the village during the  week. She wishes to get another loan to buy  a big freezer for her ice-cakes because the one she has now is very small and old.

loans.use: To buy ingredients and supplies for her ice cake (popsicle) business

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 21-year-old barber. Ali owns his barber shop in the region of Saida, in south Lebanon. Ali is uses some of his income to help his parents with their living expenses. He is requesting $1000 to improve the appearance and operation of his shop. Ali is a very determined young man who hopes to continuously upgrade his business.

loans.use: To improve the appearance and operation of his barber shop

loans.name: Munaku B(Iv) Group

texts.en:
Florence is 30 years old and married with one child. Florence, Rose and Allen all sell used clothes. Florence wants to use the extra profits to re-invest in the business. Night sells raw foods while Agnes has a beauty salon.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for sale

loans.name: Hosptial East D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rebecca N.. She is currently in the business of milling maize and is requesting a loan to purchase more maize. Rebecca is 23 years old and is single. Each week, Rebecca makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy more maize to make flour. Rebecca has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to expand her maize milling business and the loan was paid back on time.

Rebecca is joined in her small group by Lydia M. and Margret B.. Lydia M. has a business running a beauty salon and wants to buy more salon equipment like oils and braids. Margret B. is currently operating a business selling charcoal and wants a loan to boost business.

loans.use: To boost business of milling maize

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is Amina R.. She is a 38-year-old widow, and she has one 18-year-old child. In 1999, Amina established her egg business. Working six days a week, and 5 to 8 hours a day, she earns about $210 each month from this business. She is assisted by her child and two employees. Amina has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA, and now seeks a new loan in order to purchase 200 trays of eggs. In the future, Amina plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are not considered to be credit-worthy by financial institutions because they lack tangible assets that can serve as collateral. As such, low income women in Tanzania typically receive poor financial support and in turn only limited access to basic needs and services.

Fortunately, SELFINA has been a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women in Tanzania. Simply put, SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women through an arrangement called a sale and leaseback transaction. More specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extends a loan to her to facilitate the transaction, and then leases the equipment back to her.

loans.use: To purchase additional (200 trays) eggs.

loans.name: Libaña

texts.es:
Libaña belongs to the Communal Bank The Family, located in the Av. Centenario Km. 3,800, of the District of Calleria of the Department of Ucayali. She is 60 years old and is a mother of three children. Her husband is a merchant. With the first loan of 300 PEN she received from Manuela Ramos, she decided to invest it in the sale of food and frozen drinks. Currently, she sells carbonated water, sandwiches and cakes in the entrance to the factory of Gaseosas Kola Real. In the morning she spends her time at home and in the evening she leaves to sell her goods. She is very attentive to her clients, very nice and always very happy.

With this loan of 2,000 PEN (about $700), which will be paid in 4 months, she will buy carbonated water, sweets and supplies for baking cakes.

Libaña feels very good that her business is growing each day because it allows her to be able to help her family and feel more useful and independent.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Hernandez, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Libaña pertenece al Banco Comunal La Familia, ubicado en la Av. Centenario Km. 3.800, del Distrito D. Calleria del Departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 60 años es madre D. 3 hijos, su esposo es comerciante. Melita con el primer préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en la venta D. comida y bebidas heladas.

En la actualidad venD. gaseosas, sanwichs, queques en la puerta D. la fábrica D. gaseosas Kola Real, en las mañanas se dedica a su hogar y por las noches sale a vender, para tener mas clientes Libaña atienD. a sus clientes con mucha amabilidad y siempre con mucha alegría.

Con este préstamo D. S/. 2,000, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará gaseosas, golosinas, insumos para sus queques.

Libaña se siente muy bien su negocio esta creciendo día a día con mucho esfuerzo así pueD. ayudar a su familia y sentirse útil e independiente.

loans.use: With the loan she will buy more products for her business

loans.name: Que Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Que Thi N., 48 years old, joined the Fund in 2007. She raises pigs and chickens for sale. Since her last loan of 200USD last year, she was able to raise 4 pigs, each weighing around 154-176lbs and more than 100 chickens. Her husband is a construction worker and has greatly helped her during her participation with the Fund. This time around, she wishes to borrow 375USD to build breeding pens and buy more feed for her pigs. With any money leftover, she plans expand her breeding facilities for her growing number of pigs. Her present monthly income is around 150USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Trinh Quoc N., Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Quế năm nay 48 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ năm 2007. Công việc của chị là chăn nuôi lợn, gà. Từ mức vốn vay 200USD năm đầu đến nay chị đã có số vốn là 4 con lợn, mỗi con 70-80kg và hơn 100 con gà. Chồng chị làm thợ xây và hỗ trợ chị rất nhiều trong quá trình tham gia Quỹ. Vòng vốn này chị Quế xin vay mức 375USD để xây dựng chuồng trại, mua thức ăn chăn nuôi, số tiền còn lại cùng với đợt bán lợn này chị sẽ mở rộng mô hình chăn nuôi lợn. Thu nhập hàng tháng hiện nay của chị Quế là 150USD.

loans.use: Buy food for pigs

loans.name: Chanra

texts.en: Mrs. Chanra P. and her husband, Mr. Min Thai, are in the recycling business. They collect the waste such as glass bottles, plastics, and cans. They live in Kbal Domrey Village in Kampong Chhnang province. In order to make Mrs. Chanra P. and her husband's business easier, Mrs. Chanra P. needs to access a loan to afford to buy a motorbike to transport her waste to re-sell for a profit. Mrs. Chanra P. is 27 and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To afford to buy a motorbike to transport her waste to re-sell for a profit

loans.name: Awoma

texts.fr:
Born in 1952, Awoma S. is a very dynamic widow who specializes in the preparation of kom, a highly appreciated meal in the south of TOGO. She has run this business for 40 years. Not having a large enough capital base, she has been unable to maximize her profits and subsequently improve her standard of living.

Furthermore, she has not been able to satisfy the large demands of her customers. It is for all of these reasons that she is asking for a loan which will serve to buy maize, tomatoes, and fish, which are indispensable in securing a consistent income for her.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

Née en 1952, S. Awoma est une veuve très dynamique spécialité dans la préparation de kom, un repas très apprécié au sud du TOGO. Elle exerce cette activité il y a de cela 40 ans. Ne disposant pas d’un fonds de commerce assez important, elle ne parvient pas à maximiser des bénéfices pour améliorer ses conditions et niveau de vie.

Par ailleurs, elle n’arrive pas à satisfaire à la forte demande de sa clientèle. C’est pour toutes ces raisons qu’elle sollicite un crédit qui lui servira à l'achat du mais,tomates,et poissons indispensable à la sécurisation et à la consistance de son revenu.

loans.use: To buy maize, tomatoes, and fish in bulk

loans.name: Juana Maria

texts.es:
Juana Maria started her business for her children, so she would be able to offer them a better future and simultaneously to help her husband with the family expenses since his salary was quite low at the time. She began selling tamales in September 2001, thanks to her mom who encouraged her to become independent, and also because she was helping her to prepare them and to sell them. Also at this same time she was doing handycrafts only to decorate her house during the different seasons of the year and a neighbor liked them and asked her to do a few adornments for her and she bought them. This way the word spread out and more and more people were buying adornments and today she can already prepare many different adornments for different seasons of the year and for the holidays. She needs a loan of $1000 that she will repay over a period of 6 months to be able to buy material that allows her prepare her adornments and supply her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva volunteer.

Juana Maria inició el negocio por sus hijos, para brindarle un mejor futuro y a la vez ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa para no verse tan apretados económicamente, ya que el sueldo que recibía su esposo en ese tiempo era muy bajo. Comenzó en Septiembre de 2001 vendiendo tamales, gracias a su mamá que la animó a que se independizara, ya que ella le ayudaba a elaborarlos y a venderlos, también en ese tiempo hacía manualidades únicamente para adornar su casa en diferentes épocas del año y a una vecina le gustaron y le pidió que le hiciera unos adornos y se los vendiera, así se fue corriendo la voz y cada vez le fueron pidiendo mas adornos y el día de hoy ya puede elaborar muchos adornos para diferentes épocas del año y para fiestas. Ella necesita un prestamo por US $1000 que pagara en 6 meses para poder comprar material que le permita elaborar sus adornos y poder surtir a sus clientes.

loans.use: Buy merchandise.

loans.name: Oem

texts.en: Oem S., age 28, is a true entrepreneur and has a business selling vegetables at an open air market. She usually earns around US$1.50 each day. Her husband, Sok Yun, is a farmer and makes US$2 each day. This couple together has three children, one of whom is a student and others are too young to attend school. Oem is requesting a loan of US$500 to increase the number of vegetables for sale and also to start selling chicken.

loans.use: To increase the number of vegetables for sale and also to start selling chicken.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael A. sells phones and accessories at Kotokoraba, which is in the heart of the Cape Coast. Michael has received a senior high school education. He is a single parent and has three children. 

Michael has been selling phones and accessories since 2000. He is responsible for paying his children's school fees and other utility bills. His loan will be used to buy the latest mobile phones and accessories for resale. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to expand his capital base to increase his profit and enable him meet the increasing needs of his family.

loans.use: His loan will be used to buy latest mobile phones, accessories for resale.

loans.name: Nieta (Essor) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Nieta est un regroupement de dix femmes ayant en moyenne 24 ans et 4 enfants vivant en majorité dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-Coungo(deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali). Unies par des relations de mariage, de voisinage et de parenté, ces femmes font le commerce du bois de chauffe et des condiments alimentaires.
Après six prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) tous correctement remboursés, ce groupe est à son septième prêt avec le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
Elles comptent acheter, 1200 litres de lait auprès des éleveurs de Marka-Coungo et des villages environnants. Elles revendent aux grossistes venant des grandes villes telles Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali)une partie et l’autre partie est vendue dans le marché de Marka-Coungo au bord de la route  nationale N°9 reliant Bamako à Ségou en détail et au comptant.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 40 000 FCFA par mois. 
Les membres du groupe Nieta veulent ouvrir une munie laiterie à Marka-Coungo.
texts.en:
The Nieta group is comprised of ten women who, on average, are 24 years old and have 4 children. Most of them live in large traditional families in the village of Marka-Coungo (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Linked by bonds of marriage, neighborhood and family, these women sell firewood and food products. After six solidarity loans (group loans), all repaid without problems, this group is seeking its seventh loan from the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution program. They intend to buy 1'200 liters of milk from farmers in Marka-Coungo and from the surrounding villages. They resell part of it to wholesalers coming from large cities such as Bamako (the capital of the Republic of Mali), the remaining part being retailed for cash at the market of Marka-Coungo, on the side of Highway 9, linking Bamako to Ségou. They count on making each a monthly profit of XOF 40'000 (ca US$ 80). The members of the Nieta group intend to open a dairy in Marka-Coungo.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy milk

loans.name: Mrs. Sam Art Ean Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fifteen people in S. Raong village in Takeo Province, Cambodia, have formed a village bank loan group. Mrs. S. Art E. is the village bank president. She sells Prohok (crushed, salted and fermented fish paste, usually of mud fish, that is used in Cambodian cuisine as a seasoning) in the local market. Her husband, Mr. C. Dol, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. He is also a successful duck breeder and he wants to expand this business. Thus, Mrs. S. Art E. decided to request a loan to buy more ducklings and duck food to support them. She hopes to increase income and improve her living conditions with this loan. She is a 35-year-old mother of four children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school while the other is too young to work or study.

Mr. Saroeurn B. does not come to take a loan but his wife is, so she is presented in the picture instead of her husband.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Fourteen members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time.

loans.use: To buy more ducklings and duck food

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.es:
La Sra. María, tiene 54 años de edad, habita en el  barrio Batahola, en la capital de Managua,  casada su esposo es comerciante, tiene dos lindos hijos de 26 y 18 años de edad ambos los tiene estudiando en la universidad, los planes que tiene para su familia es que sus hijos tenga un patrimonio y porvenir mejor doña Maria tiene un pequeño negocio miscelánea desde hace diez años de experiencia en  las
Ventas como atención al cliente en general, iniciando con la venta de productos básico y en pocas cantidades con capital propio, sus objetivos
En el ámbito económico es ofrecer a sus clientes diversificación de productos aumentando  el volumen de venta.
Gracias a los préstamos de Afodenic logrará comprar mayores cantidades de productos como: granos básicos, perfumes, cosméticos, productos enlatados, productos de higiene personal y de hogar, generándole mayores utilidades.
texts.en:
Maria is 54-years old and lives in the Batahola neighborhood of the capital of Managua. Her husband is a merchant and they have 2 beautiful children, ages 18 and 26, who study in the university. Maria wants her children to have property and a better future. She has owned a small general store for 10 years. She began by selling basic products in small quantities with a little of her own money, with the financial objective of increasing sales by offering her customers a variety of products. Thanks to the loans from Afodenic she will be able to buy greater quantities of products such as staple grains, perfumes and cosmetics, canned food, personal hygiene products, and household items, generating higher income.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of grains and various products to stock general store

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya (composé de 4 femmes  mariées) ont une moyenne d’âge de 27 ans avec en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier  Babemba de la ville de sikasso.
Elles  exercent des activités commerciales différentes, vente de condiments, du bois de chauffe, des chaussures et des pagnes wax et real.
Elles collaborent avec  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  pour satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Les prêt précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 8 chargements de charrette de en bois de chauffe, 5 pièces de pagnes wax et real, une vingtaine de chaussures en plastique et 3colis de condiments alimentaires. Elles s’approvisionnent  sur place à Sikasso et environnants.
Les produits sont vendus en détail et la plupart au comptant dans les marchés de la ville de Sikasso (Médine et le grand marché de la ville) et dans quartier à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 12 000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt,subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Danaya group (composed of 4 married women) have an average age of 27 and on average, 3 children. They live in the Babemba neighborhood of the town of Sikasso.

They have varied commercial ventures: selling condiments, firewood, shoes, and "wax" and "real" African print cloth.

They collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy the needs of their clientele. They are on their third solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to buy 8 wagonloads of firewood, 5 lengths of wax or real African print cloth, some 20 pairs of plastic shoes and 3 bales of condiments. They do their buying right in Sikasso and its surroundings.

The items are sold retail and mostly on a cash basis in the markets of the town of Sikasso (Médine and the big open-air market of the town) and in their own neighborhoods to a clientele composed of women and men.

They each hope to make an average profit of 12,000 FCFA a month which will be used to make repayments on the loan and cover the needs of their families, re-investing any remainder in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments, firewood, shoes and lengths of African print cloth

loans.name: Dolgor

texts.en: Dolgor T. is a married young woman who lives with her husband and daughter in the center of Uvurhangai province. Uvurhangai is a one of Mongolia's southern provinces, locates 400 km from the capital city, Ulaanbaatar, and not too far from the Chinese border. Dolgor's family lives in her father in-law's yard located in a "ger" district (a ger is the traditional, nomadic form of housing in Mongolia; a ger district is where many people have settled in these homes, forming a sort of ad hoc suburb). Though they rent the land on which they set up their ger, they own the get itself. Dolgor graduated high school several years ago. After her graduation, she moved to countryside to become a herder. In 2006 she moved back to center of her province to run a retail sales business. When she begun her business she buy many small goods from others and sell them back. To expand her business, she has bought a stall last year. Now she is running her retail sales business with her husband. They sell mostly women clothes such as sweaters, blouses and jeans. But they also sell small items such as jewelry (fake), socks and so on. She or her husband goes to Ereen, a city just across the Chinese border, once or twice a month to buy goods for the business. With the lunar New Year celebration approaching, small items have sold quickly, therefore, they wants a loan to buy more small items.

loans.use: To buy small items for lunar new year sales

loans.name: Lonh

texts.en: Mrs. Lonh I. lives in Pech Sar village in Takeo province. She is a duck breeder. Her husband, Mr. Kong Kosal, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from ownI. this plantation, he makes baskets to sell to earn income. Now Mrs. Lonh I. is requestI. a loan to buy more ducks to grow her poultry business, and she would use the rest of the money to purchase rice seed and fertilizer for production in the field. She is 43 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are attendI. the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband is shown on the left of the picture.

loans.use: To buy more ducks to grow her poultry business and to purchase rice seed and fertilizer for production in the field

loans.name: Nyamdorj

texts.en: Nyamdorj D. is 31, married and father of one child. In 2002, he began to run a wholesale business. He buys slaughtered livestock from Dundgobi, one of the southern provinces of Mongolia, and resells them at an outdoor meat market in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Nyamdorj has a minibus that he used to use for transporting the animals. With his business profit, he has been able to build a house. Together with his wife, Nyamdulam, he plans to buy a condo in downtown Ulaanbaatar and save money for his child's future tuition. With this loan, he will buy a second-hand but better minibus for his business.

loans.use: To buy a minibus

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.en:
L. Tran, 45, lives in the town of Hưng yên. She is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, L. owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising cattle for sale. L. has been engaged in this business for over 25 years and earns approximately 2000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2004, L. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. L. has successfully repaid a previous L. from TYM Fund. This previous L. was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. L. is now requesting a new L. of 10000000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell.

The L. will be the fifth taken out by the borrower from TYM Fund. L. plans to use the revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Buy livestock feed and supplies.

loans.name: Vasyl

texts.en:
Vasyl sells manufactured retail items in the central market of his home town. He has been in this business for seven years. Currently, his income amounts to 5,000 Hryvnia. He is married with two beautiful daughters. His family lives in Khoost.

Vasyl can be characterized as a businessman of honesty and responsibility. His experience working in the accounting sphere has helped him manage his finances and distribute profit reasonably. Vasyl is seeking this loan of 6,000 Hryvnia to re-stock his merchandise. One of his long-term plans is to open new vending locations and expand his trade as a result.

loans.use: To refresh his inventory

loans.name: Maria Jacinta

texts.es:
La señora Maria Jacinta, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Cruz De Motupe”, vive en Prolongación Libertadores ultima cuadra Psj. Primavera s/n, Distrito de independencia – Provincia de Huaraz, Departamento de Ancash. Es casada, tiene 39 años y es madre de 02 hijos, ambos  dependen de ella.
Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300.00, compró 20 kilos de ajíes panca, de esta manera  incrementó mercadería en su negocio de venta de abarrotes y productos de limpieza. Tiene 02 años trabajando con el Banco Comunal.
En la actualidad, continúa con el mismo negocio en un puesto alquilado del mercado informal de la ciudad de Huaraz, en el cual ha sido reubicada por la Municipalidad, donde ofrece sus productos a todos los moradores de de la ciudad y público en general.  Con este crédito de S/.1,700.00 podrá comprar una mototaxi para ser trabajado por su esposo.  Para esta compra ella cuenta con un pequeño ahorro de S/.1400.00.
Hoy, se siente independiente y segura de lograr sus objetivos trazados y con muchas ganas de seguir superándose ya que gracias a los ingresos que genera su negocio puede educar a sus dos hijos.
Maria Jacinta manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por haberle facilitado el acceso a los créditos y poder crecer como empresaria.
texts.en:
Maria Jacinta is a member of the “Cruz De Motupe” Communal Bank. She lives in Prolongación Libertadores on the last block of Psj. Primavera s/n, in the Independencia District of Huaraz Province, in the Ancash Region of Peru. She is married, 39 years old and mother to 2 children who both depend on her.
With her first loan of S/. 300, she purchased 20 kilos of Panca peppers and thereby increased her grocery and cleaning products business's merchandise. She has worked with the Communal Bank for 2 years.
She currently runs the same business from a rented space at an informal market in Huaraz, where she was relocated by the Municipality. She offers her products there to all the city’s residents and the general public. With this loan of S/. 1700, she will be able to purchase a mototaxi for her husband to use. She already has S/. 1400 saved for this purchase.
Now she feels independent and confident that she will achieve her goals. She is very eager to continue succeeding now that thanks to the income her business generates she is able to educate her children.
Maria Jacinta would like to thank Manuela Ramos for providing her access to loans and helping her grow as an entrepreneur.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a mototaxi

loans.name: Oinisa

texts.en:
S. Oinisa is a 20-year-old who has been working the land for 3 years. Her husband has no fixed job, which means they have no other steady monthly income. They have a little son, their pride and joy, who is learning the best life lessons from his parents.

Their biggest source of income is the fruit of their labor; they grow potatoes and onions. Oinisa is proud of the quality of her crops and of her knowledge. While waiting for the best moment of production, she is requesting a loan in order to maintain her crops, holding off on the harvest until the market indicates that it is the best time to yield the biggest profits. Her dream is to acquire more land and produce more crops in the future because the land that she loves and has been a part of her life has allowed her to move her family forward.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing fertilizers, herbicides, and ammonium sulfate

loans.name: Thania Julia

texts.es:
Thania es socia del Banco Comunal Las Entusiastas.
Thania es soltera, tiene 48 años y 4 hijos, de profesión Agrónoma, Thania se dedica a la confección de sabanas y edredones, tiene un taller en la ciudad de Lima, sus ventas los realiza a amigos y familiares. Además Tania vende cosméticos por catálogos.
Thania necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de telas.
Thania sueña con ser una empresaria textil, sus hijos sean profesionales y que sus hijos tengan empresas.
texts.en:
Thania is a member of Banco Comunal Las Entusiastas.

Thania is single, 48 years old, has four children and is a trained agronomist. Thania works sewing curtains and comforters. She has a workshop in the city of Lima. She sells to friends and family. Thania also sells cosmetics through catalogs.

Thania needs a loan of 1000 soles, money that will be invested in the purchase of fabrics.

Thania dreams of having a textile business and that one day her children are trained and have businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fabrics

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma makes a living primarily from selling products to local community members. She is 47 years old, married and has five adult children. They are from the village of Dumagoc, Pagadian City, Zamboanga del Sur. Vilma has been in this business for over ten years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Vilma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Vilma is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Abejitas Group

texts.es:
Eulogia C. es la presidenta del grupo "Abejitas" que a su vez pertenece al Centro Focal "German Busch". Eulogia vende frutas  en diferentes ferias de la ciudad de El Alto y necesita el préstamo para incrementar su mercadería, así que con algunas vecinas y amigas de las zonas Ingavi, German Busch y Mercurio se agruparon. Las demás integrantes tambien tienen sus diferentes negocios como la venta de comida, chocolate y otras se dedican a negocios de servicio como el lustrar zapatos y transporte y otras al tejido de mantas.

El grupo espera permanecer mucho tiempo juntas y hacer uso de los servicios de Pro Mujer como la capacitación y la atención en consultorio.
texts.en:
Eulogia C. is the president of "Abejitas" Group, which at the same time belongs to "German Busch" Focal Center. Eulogia sells fruit in different markets in the city of El Alto and she needs the loan to grow her merchandise. So, with some of her neighbors and friends in the neighborhoods of Ingavi, German Busch, and Mercurio, they formed a group. The other members have their own different businesses, such as selling food and chocolate, while others dedicate themselves to service-oriented businesses, such as polishing shoes, transportation, and weaving blankets.

The group hopes to remain together for a long time and make use of the services Pro Mujer offers, such as trainings and office hours.


Translated from Spanish by Suzy Marinkovich, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For purchasing merchandise, consumables, and raw materials

loans.name: Hilda Esperanza

texts.en:
Hilda is a member of the Force and Power village bank. She is a single mother with two sons who are 21 and 18 years-old. They both work and go to school. Hilda is from Puno and came to Lima to study nursing but was not able to finish because she became pregnant. 

In order to support herself, she sold candy in the streets for the next eight years. Eventually she had to stop because street vendors were prohibited where she was selling and the police would take away the products of these vendors. Around the same time she became pregnant again and decided to start selling her goods out of her house.  Business went well and Hilda decided to expand and start selling meals at her house with her daughter’s help. 

Since joining FINCA she has gained self-confidence and has improved her economic situation. Hilda needs a loan of 800 soles to buy more rice, sugar, and noodles for the meals she sells at home. Her dream is to grow her business and continue her personal growth.

loans.use: buy more rice, sugar, and noodles for the meals she sells at home

loans.name: Akouvi Essé

texts.fr: Cette dame n’est pas mariée et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus la vente de sacs et chaussures. C’est une vendeuse ambulante ; et elle exerce ce commerce dans le quartier de Hédzranawoé à Lomé. Cette vente lui permet de satisfaire tous ses besoins et de faire des projections pour l’avenir. Actuellement elle arrive à écouler tous ses stocks car elle dispose d’un large éventail de clientèles. Pour lancer une nouvelle commande au Grand Marché de Lomé, elle sollicite un prêt de WAGES pour acheter 10 cartons de sacs de différentes catégories et 20 cartons de chaussures. Ce prêt lui sera aussi une opportunité pour louer une boutique pour la vente sur place.
texts.en:
This is a lady who is not married and has no children at all to support.  Her income-generating business involves selling bags and shoes.  She is an itinerant salesperson; and she operates in the Hédzranawoé district in Lomé.  Her sales enable her to support herself entirely and to make plans for the future.  Currently, she's managing to sell all of her inventory because she has a wide range of customers.  To initiate a new order at the Grand Market of Lomé, she's requesting a WAGES loan to buy 10 boxes of bags of different categories and 20 boxes of shoes.  This loan will also allow her the opportunity to lease a store for making sales locally.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy boxes of bags and shoes

loans.name: Nestor

texts.en:
Aside from being a farmer, Nestor has also been operating his passenger tricycle since it was being purchased on an installment basis in the year 2005. He is asking for financial assistance for the maintenance of his passenger tricycle. He is also planning to open a retailing business that his wife will look after. He hopes that through the assistance of lenders, he could easily achieve his business goals. He is asking for a loan of Php 6,000. This is all for the benefit of their only child in the future.

Nestor is already 49 years old and is married to Annalyn who is a plain housewife. They have only one child named Christian Dave who is just four years old. Christian is already studying in the primary school in kindergarten. The couple hopes that Christian will have a good future ahead of him if they provide him a complete education. Nestor hopes that as the head of the family, he’ll be a good provider to his family and someday could send his child in college until he is able to finish it.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac F. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables and beans and is requesting a loan to purchase hens and cocks to sell.

Isaac is 48 years old and is married to a husband who is a policeman. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase hens and cocks to sell

loans.name: Lucita

texts.en:
Lucita L. is from the village of Binaliwan, Mahinog Camiguin Province. Lucita is married and has school-aged children. To make a living, Lucita owns & operates a business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail business. Her main source of income from the business comes primarily from selling beauty products such as face powder, cologne, lotion and others in the local community. Lucita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lucita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucita is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Lucita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional face powder, cologne, lotion and others products to sell

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza is 27 years old.  She and her husband Victorino, a company driver, are blessed with three healthy children who are currently enrolled in elementary school. They reside in the rural village of Calaocan, Cabatuan, Isabela.  

Analiza is determined to develop her skills in managing her poultry business, which provides her with a good living. She raises chickens and sells them after 30 days for PHP 115 per kilo.  Through these sales, she generates an income of PHP 4,000 a month, which is a big help in meeting the daily needs of her family and maintaining the productivity of her business. She is requesting a loan from KIVA lenders in the amount of PHP 11,000, which she needs to purchase chicken feed and additional chicks to raise. She hopes that her business will further improve with the help of this loan.

loans.use: to purchase chicken feed and more chicks to raise

loans.name: 02.06.1.2 Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Miễn T. Thị (8) is a 50-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Miễn is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 02.06.1.2 Nam Ngạn.

Miễn is married and has three adult children. To making a living, Miễn operates a family business in the services sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing construction services to local community members. Miễn has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2007, Miễn joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Miễn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide services. She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND, which will be used to purchase more materials needed to provide services. The loan will be the fourth loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Miễn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1.  Vũ Thi Bàn (9) is a 54-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food.

2.  N. Thị Hoa (7) is a 39-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her service-based business.

3.  N. Thị Hà (11) is a 44-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector selling home products.

4.  Lê Thị Hiền (10) is a 37-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Original text:

Miễn  T. Thị (8) là 50 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá.  Miễn  là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 06.1.2 Nam Ngạn (02.06.1.2 Nam Ngạn).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ xây dựng cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Miễn  thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 10 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Miễn  kiếm được khoảng 2.000.000 VND.  Vào 2007, Miễn  đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Miễn  đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3.079.800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua vật tư cần thiết để cung cấp dịch vụ.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:

1.  Vũ Thi Bàn (9) là 54 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.

2.  N. Thị Hoa (7) là 39 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.

3.  N. Thị Hà (11) là 44 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán hàng gia dụng.

4.  Lê Thị Hiền  (10) là 37 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase materials for a construction service

loans.name: Djiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djiguiya est composé de six femmes (deux veuves et quatre mariées) qui ont en moyenne 38 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des familles monogames dans  le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles  font le commerce d’articles divers, la restauration et sont à leur 2ème prêt de groupe après avoir remboursé sans aucune difficulté le premier. 
Ce  prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter, 5 pièces de pagnes wax, 3 couvertures en laine, 3 couvre-lits, 65 habits pour enfants (des robes, complet- culottes, complet jupes et des layettes), des condiments alimentaires (150 bols de poudre de feuilles de baobab, 50 bols de piment, 1/2 carton de poisson séché, 6 paquets de maggi poulet et 60 morceaux de potasse), 3 sacs d’arachide, 5 paniers de poissons frais et 5 cartons de savons.  
Elles s’approvisionnent  en pagnes wax et savons à Bamako, en couvertures en laine et en couvre-lits à Gao, en habits  pour enfants au grand marché de Ségou, en condiments alimentaires au marché Château de Ségou, l’arachide en gousse à la foire hebdomadaire de Boussin, en poisson au marché château. La vente des  habits  pour enfants se fait en ambulant dans les quartiers de Darsalam et de Hamdallaye, les autres marchandises sont vendues au marché château, à l’exception des couvertures en laine et couvre-lits  qui le sont à domicile. 
La vente se fait au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femmes. 
Elles  comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  le remboursement des prêts, à la contribution aux charges familiales, à la participation aux évènements sociaux. 
Leurs ambitions sont : avoir  une maison et pérenniser leurs activités commerciales.
texts.en:
The Djiguiya group comprises six women (two widows and four married women) who are on average 38 years old, with an average of 4 children and living in monogomous families in the Hamdallaye area of the town of Ségou (in the 4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They sell a variety of products, as well as doing some catering, and are on their second group loan, having repaid the first without any difficulty. This loan will be used to buy 5 pieces of "pagne wax" (a West African term for highly decorative and colourful fabric), 3 woollen blankets, 3 bedcovers, 65 items of clothing for children (dresses, trouser suits, skirt suits and baby clothes), food seasonings (150 bowls of powder made from the Baobab - or monkey bread - tree, 50 bowls of chili peppers, 1/2 a carton of dried fish, 6 packets of Maggi chicken stock cubes and 60 pieces of potash) 3 bags of groundnut, 5 baskets of fresh fish and 5 cartons of soaps. They buy their stock of fabric and soaps in Bamako, the woollen blankets and bedocvers in Gao, the children's clothing at the large market at Ségou, the food seasonings and the fish at the Château de Ségou market, and the groundnut pods at the weekly fair at Boussin. They sell the children's clothing while walking around the neighbourhoods of Darsalam and Hamdallaye, and the other goods are sold at the Château market, apart from the woollen blankets and bedcovers which are sold to people in their homes. The goods are sold for either cash or credit to a customer base made up of both men and women. They are expecting to make a monthly profit of 30,000 FCFA which will be used for the repayment of loans, but also to contribute to family expenses and social events. Their ambitions are to have a house and to keep their business going.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various products

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en: Emilia is a thirty-nine year old divorced mother of one child who is currently in school. She lives with her daughter in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. She works hard to be able to meet the demands of the family. Emilia is a food vendor. She prepares and sells rice with stew, from a table top by the road side. She buys bags of rice from nearby towns. Emilia has been in business for three years and wants a loan to procure bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk so she can increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice.

loans.name: Benjamin Jose

texts.es:
El Señor Benjamin José M. Núñez, tiene la edad de 24 años, Labora como Oficial de Mantenimiento en el Mercado Roberto Huembes de Managua, el tiene un hijo a su cargo, este se encuentran  en edad escolar, es Casado, ha trabajado créditos con  CEPRODEL durante cinco años, en este periodo de tiempo ha invertido 5 créditos en el mejoramiento de la vivienda en la que habita, gracias a los financiamientos otorgados por CEPRODEL,  el es un cliente excelente.
 
El crédito solicitado es para invertir en la compra de materiales de construcción. El que utilizara para la remodelación y cambio de una parte del techo de la vivienda en la que habita, con el objetivo de darle mayor seguridad y mejores condición de vida a su hijo.

Benjamin dijo que gracias a los préstamos otorgados por ceprodel ha podido mejorar su casa de habitación.
texts.en:
Sr. Benjamin José M. Núñez is 24 years old and works as a maintenance official at the Roberto Huembes Market in Managua. He is married and has one dependent child in school. Benjamin has been working with CEPRODEL for five years and has received five loans that were used to make improvements to his home. He is an excellent client.

The loan he is requesting will be used to purchase construction materials for a remodeling project and to change out part of the roof on his house. His objective is to provide greater security and better living conditions for his son. Benjamin says he thanks CEPRODEL for providing loans so that he can make these home improvements.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.en: Esmeralda T., 37 years old, is a sari-sari store owner. She wants to grow her business so that she will be able to buy an adequate supply of food, clothing and other basic needs. She has three children. Her eldest child is 15 years old and currently a high school student. She needs additional capitalization in her business. She would like a loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise for her store so that she will be able to offer her customers a wider selection.

loans.use: To obtain additional merchandise to resell

loans.name: Ese

texts.en: Ese is a hard working woman. She is also a friendly woman. She uses her friendly skills to attract more customers to her business. She sells sarongs of various colours and shapes. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to really expand her business. She hopes for a loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She is 41 years old and married with 2 children. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports the home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell.

loans.name: Mayramkul's Group

texts.ru:
Когда во всём мире происходят перемены, и меняются жизненный уклад целых стран, отдельные люди в силу своих интеллектуальных способностей также начинают реагировать на эти изменения. Когда в странах бывшего советского союза началась меняться экономика, жизненный уклад и идеология, наиболее дальновидные люди сразу осознали необходимость заняться частным предпринимательством. Герои этой истории, оказались таковыми, так как в основном все решили работать на рынке. Молдокматова Майрамкуль – лидер группы. Майрамкуль вместе с семьёй проживает в г. Карабалта. У Майрамкуль трое детей: сын и две дочери. Майрамкуль и её муж нашли свою нишу в животноводстве. Они решили заняться перепродажей и откормом крупно – рогатого скота и занимаются этим последние шесть лет. А начали они с того, что сначала продали корову, которая у них была ранее, и купили двух бычков и занялись откормом. Сейчас от перепродажи скота они имеют доход в размере четырнадцати тысяч сомов. За последние годы они смогли приобрести авто и за счёт этого бизнеса обучают младшую дочь в университете, оплачивая её контракт. Старший сын уехал работать в Южную Корею, среднюю дочь выдали замуж, а младшая учится в университете, и параллельно работает парикмахером. Сейчас Майрамкуль и её муж нуждаются в кредите,  чтобы вложить кредитные средства в покупку 1-й коровы для дальнейшей перепродажи на рынке. В будущем они планируют построить  большой дом. 

У Майрамкуль три партнёра по группе:

Турусову Бакытбеку сорок два года. Супруга Бакытбека уехала на заработки в Россию. Бакытбек отец двух детей. Дети уже подросли. Сын работает на стройке, а дочь учится в колледже. Сам Бакытбек предоставляет услуги столяра, продаёт  изделия из дерева, ручки для топора, каталки и доски. Бакытбеку нужен кредит, чтобы купить стройматериалы.

Абдыкаимовой Салиме сорок два года. Салима мать четверых детей. Муж Салимы, работает грузчиком на рынке. Дочери работают в швейном цеху, один из сыновей ходит в школу, а другой пока ещё дошкольник. Салима занимается розничной торговлей картошки и обратилась за кредитом ,чтобы закупить картошки для продажи.

Абдыракмановой Азизахан сорок два года. Вместе с мужем они торгуют овощами на базаре. Азизахан растит пятерых детей. Старшие уже достаточно подросли, чтобы помогать родителям в торговле. Азизахан нуждается в кредите, так как ей нужны средства, чтобы закупить фрукты для увеличения ассортимента товара.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
When the whole world is changing and the way of life of entire nations is transformed, competent individuals also begin to react to the developments. When the economy, way of life, and ideology of the post-Soviet countries began to change, the most farsighted people immediately recognized the necessity of taking up private enterprise. The heroes of this story were such people; the majority of them decided to work at the market. Mayramkul M. is the leader of this group. Together with her family Mayramkul lives in the city of Karabalta. Mayramkul has three children: a son and two daughters. Mayramkul and her husband found their niche in animal husbandry. They decided to fatten and re-sell livestock and they have been in the business for the last six years. When they were starting out, they sold their cow to buy two bull-calves and fatten them up. Today they have an income of about 14 thousand som from the re-sale of animals. In the last few years they have been able to buy a car and through this business they have the means to send their youngest daughter to the university, paying her tuition. The oldest son is working in South Korea; the middle daughter is married; the youngest daughter is studying at a university and working as a hairdresser. Mayramkul and her husband need the loan to buy a cow for re-sale on the market. In the future they plan to build a large house. Mayramkul has three partners in the group: Bakytbek T. is 42 years old. Bakytbek's wife went to Russia to earn money. Bakytbek is the father of two grown children. The son works in construction, the daughter is in college. Bakytbek himself is a carpenter and sells objects made of wood such as handles for axes, dough rollers, and cutting boards. Bakytbek needs the loan to buy construction materials. Salima A. is 42 years old; she is the mother of four children. Salima's husband works as a loader at the market. Her daughters work in a sewing shop; one of her sons goes to school and the other is a preschooler. Salima sells potatoes and is requesting the loan to purchase potatoes to sell. Azizakhan A. is 42 years old. Together with her husbans she sells vegetables at the market. Azizakhan has five children. The older children are old enough to help their parents with business. Azizakhan needs to loan in order to buy fruit to increase the selection of her goods. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

Translated from Russian by Anna Melyakova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy a cow for breeding in order to resale it later

loans.name: Rosario Amparo

texts.es: La Sra. H. C. Rosario Amparo , tiene 35años de edad vive  en la casa de su hermana, con su menor hija de 13 años se dedica a laborar vendiendo ropa, trabaja en campañas cortas del gobierno como limpieza de calles es muy trabajadora y empeñosa, no le teme al trabajo, con bastante ganas de superación y de salir adelante ella con su hija, para brindarle una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Ms. H. C. Rosario Amparo is a 35-year-old woman who lives in her sister's house with her 13-year-old daughter. She sells clothes for a living and takes temporary jobs from the government, such as street cleaning. She is a very hard-working person who is not afraid to get her hands dirty. She has the desire for self-improvement and wants to get ahead in life, along with her daughter, so that she can give her a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Education

loans.name: Dil Kumari

texts.en: Mrs. Dil Kumari N. is a farmer in the village of Dolchoki. She owns a piece of land where she grows vegetables. She mostly grows green vegetables and sells in the local market in the morning and evening daily. Now she is requesting her first loan of 10,000 Nepalese rupees to buy seeds and fertilizers for her vegetable farming. She uses her income to fulfill the needs of her family.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers for her farming

loans.name: Champion. Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe Champion sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 45ans, 5 enfants et vivant dans des  familles polygames à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de condiments alimentaires, d’atiecké et de tissus à l’image de Mariam Cissé.
Avec son  prêt, Mariam Cissé compte acheter,  20 rouleaux de tissus. 
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso ville et au Burkina Faso, un pays frontalier du Mali. Elle effectue ses ventes dans les différents  marchés de Sikasso et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant. 
 Tandis que Mariam  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17.000FCFA, les autres membres du groupe espèrent obtenir 12.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée en épargne et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Les femmes du groupe Champion ambitionnent d’augmenter leur chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire leur clientèle.
texts.en:
The five members of the Champion group are married women, and are on average 45 years old, with five children and live in polygamous families in Sanoubougou I, one of several populous neighbourhoods in Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). This is their first collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, with the purpose of satisfying their customers’ needs. They run different businesses, among which the sale of food condiments, atiécké (cassava-based food preparation), and clothing fabrics (as with Mariam Cissé). With her portion of the loan Mariam Cissé will buy 20 bolts of cloth. She gets her supplies from the main market in Sikasso and from Burkina Faso, a country adjacent to Mali. She resells in the various markets of Sikasso and in the neighbourhoods, to a customer base of both men and women, and generally for cash. Whereas Mariam expects her average monthly earnings to reach 17,000 FCFA, the other group members are hoping for 12,500 FCFA, of which part will be put into savings and the remainder invested in the commercial activities. The women in the Champion group have the ambition to increase customer satisfaction and consequently their turnover.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing fabric

loans.name: Ahadi Group

texts.fr:
Tabu E. est présidente du groupe de crédit  Ahadi, elle lève sa main sur la photo, âgée de 55 ans, Mariée, mère de 8 enfants parmi lesquels 4 étudient convenablement et d’autres sont déjà adultes.
